docs.abstract: Market for office condominiums in Manhattan, niche market since 1970s, has recently become more popular as prices have fallen; photos (M)

headline.main: Demand for Office Condos Grows in Manhattan

docs.snippet: A niche market since the 1970s, office condominiums have recently become more popular as prices have fallen.
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Progressive Credit Union began negotiations to renew the lease for its 9,800-square-foot office near Penn Station in Manhattan, the landlord offered terms that would have more than doubled the rent, to $40 per square foot. The credit union's treasurer and chief executive, Robert Familant, rejected the offer.

docs.abstract: Group of mothers demanding justice says the family of one victim of the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre in Beijing, China, is in discussions with the police about compensation (S)

headline.main: China: Tiananmen Payment Discussed, Activists Say

docs.snippet: A group of mothers demanding justice for those who died during the Tiananmen Square massacre said Tuesday that police officials in Beijing had contacted one family in April to discuss compensation.
docs.lead_paragraph: A group of mothers demanding justice for the victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre of June 4, 1989, said Tuesday that police officials in Beijing had contacted one family in April to discuss giving compensation for the death in that family. It was a rare instance in which officials had mentioned compensation in relation to the killings. However, the group said in a letter circulated on the Internet that the police officials did not talk about revealing the truth of the killings, legal redress or the possibility of addressing each case. Instead, ''they simply raised the issue of how much money should be given and stressed that this is for individuals, not the group as a whole,'' said the letter, which had 127 signatures. The group said: ''The bottom line is this: the souls of those killed during June 4 shall not be defiled; their families shall not be dishonored.''

headline.main: In China, a Search for the 'True' Self

docs.snippet: At a cross-disciplinary arts forum in Beijing, established artists advised members of the emerging generation not to merely follow formulas offered by the academies.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- At the Central Conservatory of Music last week, dozens of artists spoke passionately about the struggle for creativity in China amid the cacophony of money-making, Communist Party politics and cultural traditions that discourage individuality. ''What is real music?'' asked Shaosheng Lee, a student of composition and piano, speaking at ''A Cross Boundary Forum on the New Music of China,'' a three-day event tied to the Beijing Modern Music Festival.

headline.main: Defending Dissident Artist, Hong Kong Takes Role as Chinese Rebel

docs.snippet: The Hong Kong International Art Fair voiced support for Ai Weiwei in defiance of his arrest in Beijing, with one of his works on sale at the event and satellite shows paying hommage to the artist.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG -- The Hong Kong International Art Fair ended this week with a record 63,500 visitors and top sales driven in part by wealthy Chinese buyers. But there were no signs that the local Hong Kong government or event organizers had buckled under pressure to remove contentious materials that might have been off-putting to Beijing.

docs.abstract: Curators at CCD 300 gallery festival in Beijing are forced to close and dismantle the exhibition, which included a blank wall with detained artist Ai Weiwei's name below; three festival organizers seem to have disappeared (M)

headline.main: A Chinese Art Show Makes a Statement, and Is Closed

docs.snippet: BEIJING -- As an act of subversion, the empty wall unveiled Wednesday afternoon inside the CCD 300 gallery was rather tame. The defiance apparently came in appending the name Ai Weiwei below the blank space.      Lin Bing, one of the show's organizer

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Li Bibo contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- As an act of subversion, the empty wall unveiled Wednesday afternoon inside the CCD 300 gallery was rather tame. The defiance apparently came in appending the name Ai Weiwei below the blank space. Lin Bing, one of the show's organizers, described the void as a melancholy reference to the plight of Mr. Ai, who has now spent two months in police custody and is accused of economic crimes. ''We feel regret because his voice can't be heard,'' Mr. Lin told Reuters on Wednesday.

docs.snippet: Balancing diplomatic necessities with growing nationalistic impulses is proving difficult for Beijing.
docs.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG -- Appropriately, the meeting straddled the anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen massacre. Defense ministers and top brass from the United States, China and a host of lesser regional powers were in Singapore for meetings known as the Shangri-La Dialogue. Just as June 4 in Beijing ended many illusions about the nature of the Communist Party of China, so events of the past year have stripped away many illusions about the country's ''peaceful rise.'' No longer does the region assume that peace is a given and Chinese economic growth will not create other problems. Instead, the focus is on managing conflicts and attempting to allay mutual suspicions through dialogue.

docs.abstract: China's troubled Railway Ministry lowers the top operating speed for its flagship Beijing-to-Shanghai bullet train, set to open this month (M)

headline.main: High-Speed Trains in China To Run Slower, Ministry Says

docs.snippet: BEIJING -- China's troubled Railway Ministry on Monday lowered the top operating speed for its flagship Beijing-to-Shanghai bullet train, which is set to open later this month, scaling down what was supposed to be a pinnacle of a transformed rail sys

byline.original: By IAN JOHNSON; Michael Wines contributed reporting, and Shi Da contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- China's troubled Railway Ministry on Monday lowered the top operating speed for its flagship Beijing-to-Shanghai bullet train, which is set to open later this month, scaling down what was supposed to be a pinnacle of a transformed rail system that has become one of the country's proudest and most ambitious domestic initiatives. The new line, once set to run at up to 236 miles per hour, will instead run trains at 186 and 155 miles per hour, the ministry announced.

docs.abstract: A Britain-based sculptor calls off a showing of his work in Beijing, where a Chinese artist has been detained for two months.

headline.main: Anish Kapoor Cancels China Plans to Protest Ai Weiwei Detention

docs.snippet: A Britain-based sculptor calls off a showing of his work in Beijing, where a Chinese artist has been detained for two months.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Britain-based sculptor Anish Kapoor has decided to cancel plans to show his work at the National Museum of China in Beijing, a protest against the Chinese government's detention of Ai Weiwei, the artist, architect and social critic who has been in custody in an undisclosed site for two months.

docs.abstract: The exhibition is scheduled to run from June 29 to Aug. 14.

headline.main: Asia Society Plans Exhibition of Ai Weiwei New York Photos

docs.snippet: The exhibition is scheduled to run from June 29 to Aug. 14.
docs.lead_paragraph: Long before he was a star of the international art world and a target of the Chinese government, the artist Ai Weiwei was at the center of an obscure group of Chinese cultural emigr√©s in the East Village, a community that he documented in some 10,000 photographs in the decade that he lived there, from 1983 to 1993. Now, while Mr. Ai remains under detention in China, without formal charges, the Asia Society is preparing to open an exhibition of 227 of his New York photographs. They show not only important East Village events like Wigstock and local characters like Allen Ginsberg, but also humble gatherings in Mr. Ai's Third Street apartment featuring people like the artist Xu Bing, the filmmaker Chen Kaige and the composer Tan Dun, all now major Chinese cultural figures who were then toiling in immigrant obscurity.

docs.abstract: Chinese Foreign Ministry announces that Libya's opposition leader Mahmoud Jibril will visit Beijing for talks, latest sign that China is hedging its bet on survival of Col Mummar el-Qaddafi's government (M)

headline.main: Rebel Leader From Libya Is Scheduled To Visit China

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )

docs.snippet: China says Libya’s opposition leader Mahmoud Jibril will visit this week, dealing a setback to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- The chairman of the Libyan opposition's executive board, Mahmoud Jibril, will visit Beijing for talks on Tuesday and Wednesday, the Chinese Foreign Ministry announced on Monday, in the latest sign that China is hedging its bet on the survival of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's government in Tripoli. The Chinese government has criticized NATO's air campaign in Libya as excessive and called for a cease-fire, although China abstained instead of exercising its veto when the United Nations Security Council voted in March to authorize the NATO action.
